subject: Change ownership of boost::req to crow::req
commitMessage:
Change ownership of boost::req to crow::req

req is being created later, in the connection life cycle. req was
holding many important values when it was passed to authenticate, so the
authenticate call had to be refactored to includes all the data req was
holding.

Also uses of req before handle have been changed to direct calls to
boot::parse

Tested:
Made a request that did not require authentication
$ curl -vvvv --insecure "https://192.168.7.2:18080/redfish/v1"
Got correct service root

Made a unauthenticated request (Chassis)
$ curl -c cjar -b cjar -k -H "Content-Type: application/json" -X GET https://192.168.7.2:18080/redfish/v1/Chassis
Unauthenticated

Made a log-in request
$ curl -c cjar -b cjar -k -H "Content-Type: application/json" -X POST https://192.168.7.2:18080/login -d "{\"data\": [ \"root\", \"0penBmc\" ] }"

Made (same) Chassis request
$ curl -c cjar -b cjar -k -H "Content-Type: application/json" -X GET https://192.168.7.2:18080/redfish/v1/Chassis

Tested the websockets using scripts/websocket_test.py
Websockets continued to work after this change.

Followed the mTLS instructions here https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/security/TLS-configuration.md
mTLS continues to work after this change.

Change-Id: I78f78063be0331be00b66349d5d184847add1708
Signed-off-by: John Edward Broadbent <jebr@google.com>

This flow is a little subtle, because we release the Request object halfway through this method.  I wonder if we'd be better off doing the release right after cancelDeadlineTimer(), then keep the rest of this methods code using req, that way the code looks consistent.

Just a thought.... still not sure if it's better.
Sounds reasonable.
presumably this comment can go away?
Done
No need for comments like this.  I can see from the flow it's for auth.  Also, if this is for auth, move it down to 568.
Done. Everything from 547 to 568 are used for auth
OOOF........   we need a better structure here.  We can't be constructing a map every single request.  Maybe a "auth header" struct?  I need to think more about that.

I can pass the parser object directly into authorization::authenticate. 
But that felt messy. 
I can create a struct and add it to req object?

I'm still not in love with us making a copy of all this stuff.  I wonder if we could get away with passing a const boost::beast::http::fields&, via parser->get().base()

That would pass in the full set of headers without explicitly needing to construct a new map.
Map is gone, and we are passing parser->get().base(), let me know what you think.
in this context, I don't think req is used anymore, and in this scope it's invalid.  can it be removed?

It is holding url, session, and ipAddress, all used by authenticate.
I can maybe add a headerValues Struct to req?

session isn't used anymore...... and I'm a little surprised authenticate uses ipAddress????

(reading code..... one sec).
Ug.... yeah, it uses it for a really mediocre reason.  Lets just add ip address to authenticate() as well.
Yay.... spagetification..........  I'll look at this next week and give a better idea;  There must be a cleaner way to do this, but I'm not seeing it.

req has been removed, and sendUnauthorized take some string_views (url, user-agent, accept)

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/45175/12..17/include/forward_unauthorized.hpp
Do we want to change this to just be "URL", as that's the only thing we use out of the request at this point.
yeah, we can do that
Many were in request now that we built the request later...

Can we do a little more testing? 
Make sure the GUI works, websockets work? 
Maybe Mutual TLS ?

I will do more testing, but I don't know how to test the websockets. Where should I look for documentation on how I would do that? 

Also, if they are useful test, I might try to automate them later.
check the scripts directory.  There's a quick python script for starting up a simple websocket.

Easiest way to test websockets is probably the GUI. 
The GUI uses them in the following places: https://github.com/openbmc/webui-vue/search?q=websocket 
E.g. Serial Over Lan. 

Otherwise you can test something like Serial Over Lan using 
wss://$bmc/console0

You need this meson option enabled (it is enabled by default)

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/e8204933be90353ef672e62dc628448173279e1c/meson_options.txt#L16
Or yeah as Ed mentioned https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/scripts/websocket_test.py
can we remove?
removed. good catch.

Hi,Ed
I found that the ip address is always ipv6, even if the client is ipv4.
For example: if the client's ip address is 100.2.45.3, req->ipAddress.to_string() will output "::ffff:100.2.45.3".
Is this our design?

I did not expect that to change, from looking at the code. 

I will try to replicate this. How are you testing this?

zhanghaicheng,

I'm assuming that that behavior you're seeing is unrelated to this patch?  Looking at the diff, I can't see how this would've caused that behavior change.  If so, please ask on a different forum (the mailing list or discord).  The author of the ip address patch is there, and can hopefully give you some help.
Agree this seems unrelated to the patch

Ed & Gunnar:
Yes, this is unrelated to this patch.
I'm not sure if this is a problem, so I'm here to consult you. 
Thanks.
